importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article, indicating when the White House announced the use of tariff revenue to fund WIC during the government shutdown.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The start of fiscal year 2026, during which the federal government shutdown disrupted funding for WIC, triggering the need for emergency measures.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration plans to use tariff revenue—specifically from Section 32 tariffs—to fund the WIC program during the government shutdown, avoiding the use of Section 232 tariff revenue as initially proposed.
The WIC program, which supports nearly 7 million pregnant women, new mothers, and young children, was at risk of shutting down due to lack of congressional funding for fiscal year 2026.
The Treasury Department manages tariff revenue in a general fund, but this money is effectively frozen without a congressional appropriation authorizing its specific use.
Legal experts question whether the White House has the authority to redirect tariff funds to WIC without congressional authorization, citing that Congress has not appropriated funds for the program.
The National WIC Association acknowledges the intent to preserve operations but expresses concern over unknowns about funding levels, timing, and duration.
WIC has bipartisan support, and Republicans, including House Speaker Mike Johnson, have criticized Democrats for causing the shutdown and its impact on vulnerable populations.
Section 232 tariffs are imposed for national security reasons and have been applied to aluminum, steel, and cars; the total tariff revenue collected so far this year is $190 billion.
WIC provides essential nutrition support including infant formula, baby food, fruits, vegetables, and breastfeeding support.
The program had 6.9 million participants in May 2025, a significant increase from previous years due to improved enrollment access and rising food costs.

Funding for WIC is capped, and even after the shutdown, advocates warn that the program may face cuts unless Congress increases funding—current proposals in Congress offer flat or slightly increased funding, falling short of actual needs.

namedEntities.name: White House
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The executive branch office of the U.S. President, responsible for policy announcements and administration decisions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House announced a plan to use tariff revenue to fund WIC during the government shutdown, demonstrating its role in addressing federal funding gaps during political impasses.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. federal government leadership under President Donald Trump, including executive decisions and policy initiatives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration proposed redirecting tariff revenue to the WIC program, highlighting its policy response to the government shutdown and its emphasis on protecting vulnerable populations.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal food assistance program that provides nutrition support to pregnant women, new mothers, and young children.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIC is central to the article as it is the program at risk of closure during the shutdown, and the administration's proposed funding solution directly addresses its sustainability.

namedEntities.name: Section 32 tariffs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A category of tariffs that typically support child nutrition programs; used in this article to fund WIC.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Section 32 tariff revenue is being redirected to fund WIC during the shutdown, marking a specific policy decision tied to existing revenue streams and program needs.

namedEntities.name: Section 232 tariffs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tariffs imposed on goods for national security reasons; applied to aluminum, steel, and cars.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Originally proposed to fund WIC, Section 232 revenue was later replaced by Section 32 revenue due to legal and administrative concerns.

namedEntities.name: National WIC Association
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The advocacy group representing WIC program stakeholders.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The association expressed cautious support for the tariff funding plan but emphasized the lack of transparency regarding funding levels and timelines.

namedEntities.name: Chris Towner
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Towner challenged the legality of redirecting tariff funds to WIC, emphasizing that Congress must authorize spending before funds can be used.

namedEntities.name: House Speaker Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The current Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Johnson criticized Democrats for causing the shutdown and blamed them for the impact on WIC and other government programs.

namedEntities.name: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A senior Democratic leader in the U.S. Senate.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Schumer was cited by House Speaker Johnson as someone who engaged in political maneuvering that contributed to the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal agency responsible for agricultural and food policy, including WIC oversight.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The USDA informed state agencies of funding gaps and offered up to $150 million in contingency funds to prevent WIC from shutting down.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article was reported and published by CNN, providing public access to the political and policy developments surrounding the WIC funding issue.

namedEntities.name: Axios
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Axios was the first to report on the White House’s effort to use tariff funds for WIC, indicating early media coverage of the policy move.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The 45th President of the United States.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s administration initiated and promoted the tariff-based funding plan for WIC, reflecting his broader economic and political policies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During a government shutdown in October 2025, the Trump administration announced that it would redirect tariff revenue—specifically from Section 32 tariffs, which traditionally supports child nutrition programs—to fund the WIC program, which serves nearly 7 million pregnant women, new mothers, and young children. The move was made to prevent the program from closing due to a lack of federal funding, as Congress had not passed a fiscal year 2026 spending bill. While the National WIC Association welcomed the effort, it expressed concern over uncertainty about funding amounts, delivery timelines, and duration. Legal experts question the administration’s authority to use tariff funds without congressional appropriation, and the USDA has offered limited contingency support. The initiative reflects broader political tensions, with bipartisan support for WIC and Republican leaders blaming Democrats for the shutdown. Despite the temporary solution, advocates stress the need for long-term, stable funding to prevent cuts and ensure access to essential nutrition for vulnerable families.
title: White House says it will use tariff revenue to fund federal food aid for mothers and young children
